div.p: A transport resource describes an activity that can be performed and tracks the state of completion of that activity. It is a representation that an activity should be or has been initiated, and eventually, represents the successful or unsuccessful completion of that activity.

Note that there are a variety of processes associated with making and processing orders. Some orders may be handled immediately by automated systems but most require real world actions by one or more humans. Some orders can only be processed when other real world actions happen, such as a patient presenting themselves so that the action to be performed can actually be performed. Often these real world dependencies are only implicit in the order details.

div.h3: Using Transports in a RESTful context
div.p: In a RESTful context, a server functions as a repository of transports. The server itself, or other agents are expected to monitor transport activity and initiate appropriate actions to ensure transport completion, updating the status of the transport as it proceeds through its various stages of completion. These agents can be coordinated, following well choreographed business logic to ensure that transports are completed. Transport management may also be centrally controlled using some form of a workflow engine, in which case, the workflow engine itself may update and maintain the transport resources in the server, and through its orchestration activities ensure that transports are completed. The transport resource enables either model of transport management yet provides a consistent view of the status of transports being executed in support of healthcare workflows.

The assignment of transports into categories by type of transport, type of performer and transport status enable the server to function as a queue of work items. This queue can be polled or subscribed to by various agents, enabling automation of workflows in FHIR using existing search and subscription mechanisms. Owners, requesters, other agents (e.g. workflow managers) can thus be ready to initiate the next steps in a complex workflow.

Transports start in a Created state. Once they have been assigned to an owner they transition to the Ready state, indicating that they are ready to be performed. Once the owner initiates activity on the transport, the transport transitions to the In Progress state, indicating that work is being performed. Upon normal completion, the transport enters the Completed state. If there is a failure during the transport execution that prevents the transport from being completed, it can also enter a Failed state, indicating an abnormal termination of the transport. A transport in any non-terminal state may also be Cancelled, representing an abnormal termination of the transport due to external forces, rather than an error condition.

Transports in any non-terminal state (Created, Ready, In Progress) can be suspended and resumed. When a transport is suspended, it is typically resumed in the state it was in when it was originally suspended. Suspending a transport suspends all of its children as well. Resuming a transport resumes all of its children.

An In-progress transport can also be stopped, returning it to a Ready state. This may be in preparation for delegation or reassignment (e.g., because it cannot be completed by the current owner), to restart a transport due to a temporary failure (e.g., to reattempt completion of the activity), or in preparation to allow others to claim the transport.

The transport history allows applications monitoring the state of a workflow to identify transports that are long running, perhaps stuck in some queue, to enable management activities that could ensure completion. It also enables tracking of transport statistics such as wait time, or time in progress, or time to completion, enabling capture of important transport metrics in support of optimization and quality improvement.

blockquote.p: Note: Currently, transport pre-requisites can be represented using Transport's `description` element or the RequestGroup resource. We are seeking input from the implementer community in evaluating whether there is need for adding another mechanism to this resource for this purpose.

div.p: Transport spans both intent and event and tracks the execution through to completion. A Transport is a workflow step such as cancelling an order, fulfilling an order, signing an order, merging a set of records, admitting a patient. In contrast, Procedures are actions that are intended to result in a physical or mental change to or for the subject (for example, surgery, physiotherapy, training, counseling). A Transport resource often exists in parallel with clinical resources. For example, a Transport could request fulfillment of a ServiceRequest ordering a Procedure that would result in a Procedure, Observation, DiagnosticReport, ImagingStudy or similar resource. Another example would be a Transport that requests fulfillment of a CommunicationRequest to be performed between various actors.

As stated above, the transport resource tracks the state of a transport, enabling systems to ensure that transports are completed. This information is kept separate from the operational details necessary to complete the transport, as those details vary across and even within workflows. That detail is expected to be carried in the referenced `focus` of the transport.

Transports may have named inputs and outputs. Inputs represent information that may or must be present in order for a transport to complete. Outputs represent intermediate or final results produced by a transport. For example, in a transport supporting reading of radiology image, the inputs might include both the imaging study to be read, as well as relevant prior images. Outputs could represent radiology measurements as well as the Radiologist's diagnostic report.
Inputs and outputs are tracked by the transport because workflow management activity may automate the transfer of outputs from one transport to inputs to a subsequent transport.

To facilitate the integration of off the shelf workflow applications with FHIR, the transport resource may reference a definition. This definition can represent a description of the workflow activity to be performed, using a standard workflow description language such as BPEL, BPMN, or XPDL, a workflow definition such as those defined in IHE profiles, or even simple written instructions explaining a process to be performed.
